metadata.title: Chronic exposure to graphene-based nanomaterials induces behavioral deficits and neural damage in Caenorhabditis elegans

sections.text: Keywords: graphene; graphene quantum dots; C. elegans; behavioral deficits; neurotoxicity

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Graphene-based nanomaterials are a family of important engineered nanomaterials with unique properties and potential applications (Yang et al., 2010; Bitounis et al., 2013). Graphene nanoplatelet (G) is two-dimensional layers of carbon atoms arranged in a hexagonal crystalline structure. Graphene has many extraordinary physicochemical properties, notably the exceptionally high surface area, electron and thermal conductivity, and mechanical strength aspects (Novoselov et al., 2004, 2005). Since Geim discovered graphene in 2004 (Nobel Prize in Physics for this discovery), application of graphene and its derivatives has dramatically increased in the past decade (Goenka et al., 2014; Nezakati et al., 2014). Now graphene and its derivatives are widely used in diverse nanobiotechnological applications, such as in the environment, biomedicine and biotechnology. These graphene-based nanomaterials are utilized especially in biosensing (Shao et al., 2010), drug delivery (Zhang et al., 2010a), diagnosis devices (Akhavan et al., 2012) and antiviral or antitumor treatments (Akhavan and Ghaderi, 2010; Yang et al., 2012). As a result of their interaction with biological systems, there are more and more concerns about potential toxicity risks on organisms or humans.
Graphite oxide (GO) and graphene quantum dots (GQDs) are two classic types of graphene derivatives. GO is a compound of carbon, oxygen and hydrogen in variable ratios, obtained by treating graphite with strong oxidizers. GQDs are a single-layer to tens of layers of graphene of a size less than 30nm and have fascinating chemical stability, electronic properties and photoluminescence (Perreault et al., 2015). GO and GQDs have
various important applications in bioimaging, drug delivery, photodetectors, a fluorescent material and biosensors fabrication (Perreault et al., 2015; Thakur et al., 2016). Given extensive applications of graphene-based nanomaterials, a number of in vitro and in vivo toxicological studies have evaluated the interactions of these nanomaterials with various living systems such as microbes, mammalian cells and animal models (Chang et al., 2011; Yuan et al., 2012; Yang et al., 2013a; Zhi et al., 2013; Qu et al., 2013; Lalwani et al., 2016). Some studies have suggested cytotoxicity and several aspects of adverse effects on animals, such as pulmonary toxicity and immunotoxicity induced by GO exposure (Chang et al., 2011; Yuan et al., 2012; Zhi et al., 2013). Others studies also showed the intracellular accumulation and cytotoxicity of GQDs (Chong et al., 2014; Yuan et al., 2014). Despite great consideration in the safety of nanomaterials, comparatively little is known to date about the negative effects that exposure to graphene-based nanomaterials may have on the nervous system, including neural damages or degeneration (Cupaioli et al., 2014). Indeed, nanomaterials can enter organisms and may cross the blood–brain barrier to reach the central nervous system,
*Correspondence to: Defu He, Lab of Toxicology, School of Ecological and Environmental Sciences, East China Normal University, 500# DongChuan RD, Shanghai, 200241, China. E-mail: dfhe@des.ecnu.edu.cn
aLab of Toxicology, School of Ecological and Environmental Sciences, East China Normal University, 500# DongChuan RD, Shanghai 200241, China
bShanghai Key Laboratory for Urban Ecological Processes and Eco-Restoration, East China Normal University, Shanghai 200241, China
J. Appl. Toxicol. 2017 Copyright © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
where they have been suspected to impair nervous functions (Iqbal et al., 2013; Cupaioli et al., 2014). So far, neurotoxicological studies on graphene-based nanomaterials are scarce, especially in vivo.
The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has emerged as an important animal model with the properties of a short life cycle, transparent body, ease of handling, well-defined anatomy, and well-described genetic and molecular backgrounds (Zhang and Wang, 2008; Li et al., 2016). Besides, C. elegans has been shown to be very sensitive to various environmental toxicants. In addition, C. elegans contains 302 neurons and its neuronal lineage is fully described, it is advantageous as a model organism for neurotoxicology study. Caenorhabditis elegans lacks a functional blood–brain barrier. Once chemical molecules are absorbed, they may quickly diffuse into the nervous system. So far, C. elegans has been considered as an important non-mammalian alternative model for toxicity assessment and elucidation of the underlying mechanisms.
The objective of this study is to investigate and compare the potential neurotoxicity of typical graphene-based nanomaterials, G, GO and GQDs, using C. elegans. After various assays for physicochemical properties, three graphene-based nanomaterials were respectively chronically exposed. Behavior changes were assayed by testing the endpoints of body bends, head thrashes, pharynx pumping and crawling behavior. Distributions of these nanomaterials were systematically examined. Using fluorescently labeled transgenic nematodes, the effects on dopaminergic neurons, GABAergic neurons and glutamatergic neurons were further investigated. These results were finally applied to assess and compare the neurotoxicity of the graphene-based nanomaterials.

sections.heading: Nanomaterials and their characterization
sections.text:
Graphene-based nanomaterials were purchased from Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech. Co., Ltd. ( Jiangsu, China). Morphology of the graphene-based nanomaterials was investigated using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, H-7650 120 kV Automatic TEM, Hitachi, Japan) and scanning electronmicroscopy (SEM, Nova NanoSEM 450, FEI, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of G, GO and GQDs was carried out using an ESCALAB 250 spectrometer (Shanghai, China) with a mono X-Ray source AlKα excitation (1486.6 eV). The C1s and O1s spectra of XPS were fitted and decomposed using XPSPEAK41 software. Photoluminescence excitation (PLE) spectrum (Cary 100 UV–vis spectrophotometer; Agilent Technologies, Inc., Australia) was used to analyze the photometric properties of GQDs.
C. elegans Strains and exposure
All strains of C. elegans were obtained from the Caenorhabditis Genetics Center (University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, USA) and maintained according to standard protocols as previously described (Brenner, 1974). Wild-type (Bristol, N2) and transgenic strains were used, including BZ555 (dat-1p::GFP; green fluorescent protein [GFP] visible in dopaminergic neurons) (Maduro and Pilgrim, 1996), EG1285 (unc-47p::GFP+ lin-15(+); GFP expressed in GABAergic neurons) (White et al., 1986) and DA1240 (eat-4::GFP+ lin-15(+); GFP expressed in glutamatergic neurons) (Lee et al., 1999). Nematodes were maintained on
nematode growth medium (NGM) plates seeded with E. coli OP50 at 20°C (Brenner, 1974). According to previous methods (Chen et al., 2014; Xu et al., 2016), adult animals were collected into tubes by washing plates with M9 buffer and then dissolved in bleaching solution (0.45M NaOH, 2% HClO) to collect eggs. The eggs were hatched on the plates with food and then synchronized for experiments.
G, GO or GQDs suspension solutions were prepared in Kmedium (32mmol l 1 KCl, 51mmol l 1 NaCl), and the control group is K-medium. Before exposure, suspension solutions were sonicated at 100W m 2 for 1 h in an ultrasonic bath (KQ-100; Kunshan, China). Caenorhabditis elegans were exposed to a series of concentrations of G, GO or GQDs (1–100mg l 1) in the 24-well plates. During exposure, suspension solutions were shaken slightly for 30min every 12 h in the table concentrator (TS-1; Shanghai, China). Each well contained 50–100 age-synchronized nematodes. Four replicates were used for each exposure group. Nematodes were exposed for 6 days from L1 stage.

sections.heading: Distribution observation
sections.text: After C. elegans were exposed to G, GO or GQDs solutions for 6 days, nematodes were washed three times with M9 buffer, and then transferred to agar-padded slides. Worms were sealed with a coverslip which was immobilized with 100mM sodium azide. To observe the distribution of G or GO, images of nematodes were captured in a microscopy imaging system. In nematodes exposed to GQDs, images of immobilised worms were captured to assay the fluorescence intensity of GQDs by a fluorescence microscope (LEICA DM400 B; Leica Microsystems Company, Shanghai, China). Fluorescence intensity was quantified with h Image-Pro Plus software. The average fluorescence intensity of the different dose groups was calculated for quantitative analysis.

sections.heading: Lethality assays
sections.text: Synchronized nematodes were exposed to G, GO or GQDs of different concentrations (5, 10, 50 and 100mg l 1) for 6 days. The lethal experiments were performed in 24-well plates; and eachwell contained approximately 30 nematodes and 50-μl E. coli OP50 solutions for food. To prevent eggs from hatching, 0.33μl of fluoro-29-deoxyuridine (150mM) was added to each well. The numbers of dead nematodes were recorded on the first, third and sixth day, respectively. Dead nematodes were identified as unresponsive to a gentle prod of the body with a needle probe. Each experiment was run in quadruplicate.

sections.heading: Local movement
sections.text:
Head thrashing, body bending and pharynx pumping were utilized to evaluate the locomotion behaviors of nematodes (Zhang and Wang, 2008). After exposure, C. elegans was transferred to fresh (NGM) plates without food. After a minute of recovery, head thrashes, and body bending were counted for 1min and 30 s, respectively (Tsalik and Hobert, 2003). For the pharynx pumping assay, nematodes were transferred to another NGM plates, and the number of pumps was counted in 30 s. Head thrashing was defined as a change in the direction of bending of the mid body. Body bending was defined as a change in the direction of the worm corresponding to the posterior bulb of the
J. Appl. Toxicol. 2017Copyright © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/jat
pharynx along the y-axis, assuming the worm was traveling along the x-axis.

sections.heading: Analysis of locomotor video
sections.text: After exposure to G, GO or GQDs, C. elegans was transferred to fresh (NGM) plates. After 1min of adaptation, videos of nematodes were recorded for 1min using the Motic microscope and Images Advanced 3.2 software (Motic Electric Group, Xiamen, China). Locomotion videos were further analyzed by Wormlab software (MBF Bioscience, Hong Kong, China). The crawling tracks, including forward and backwards, were calculated using the midpoint of the body in terms of references (Donnelly et al., 2013; Gallagher et al., 2013). Crawling speeds were recorded in real-time during the crawling process using a bin width of 0.125 s. The body bending angle was classified as a bend angle mid-point of less than 90° from the initial trajectory, after a reversal of body bends. A dorsal or ventral bend was scored if the bend angle had changed (Chen et al., 2014; Li et al., 2016).

sections.heading: Dopamine neurons analysis
sections.text: In the BZ555 strain of C. elegans, dat-1 and GFP were co-expressed in neurons; therefore, bright GFP was observable in dopamine neuronal soma and its axons ( Jadiya et al., 2011). After exposure to G, GO or GQDs for 6days, worms were washed three times with M9 buffer to remove adhering bacteria, and then transferred to agar-padded slides and sealed with a coverslip which was immobilized with 100mM sodium azide. Images of immobilized worms were captured to assay dopamine neurons in control and exposed groups by a fluorescence microscope (LEICA DM400 B; Leica Microsystems Company, Shanghai, China). The fluorescence intensity of GFP was quantified through Image-Pro Plus software. The intensities of fluorescent puncta for dopaminergic neurons were examined in at least 30 nematodes in each group (Li et al., 2016).

sections.heading: GABAergic neurons assay
sections.text: In transgenic C. elegans strain EG1285, GABAergic neurons are visualized by the translational expression of GFP driven by the promoter of the γ-amino butyric acid transporter (unc-47::GFP) (White et al., 1986). After exposure to graphene-based nanomaterials for 6 days, nematodes were washed with M9 buffer to remove adhering bacteria, and then transferred to agar-padded slides and sealed with a coverslip which was immobilized with 100mM sodium azide. Images of immobilized worms were captured to assay GABAergic neurons by a fluorescence microscope (LEICA DM400 B; Leica Microsystems Company). Fluorescence intensity of GFP was quantified through Image-Pro Plus software. The intensities of fluorescent puncta for GABAergic neurons were examined in each group (more than 30 nematodes).

sections.heading: Assay of glutamatergic neurons
sections.text:
Glutamatergic neurons were labeled using the green fluorescent protein with eat-4::GFP in the transgenic strain DA1240 nematodes (Lee et al., 1999). After exposure to graphene-based nanomaterials for 6 days, nematodes were transferred to agarpadded slides, and then immobilized with 100mM sodium
azide. Images of worms were captured to assay glutamatergic neurons using a fluorescence microscope (LEICA DM400 B; Leica Microsystems Company). Fluorescence intensity of GFP was quantified using Image-Pro Plus software. The intensities of fluorescent puncta for glutamatergic neurons were examined in each group.

sections.heading: Statistical analysis
sections.text: All data were expressed as the mean± standard error of the mean (SEM). The mean differences between treated groups and controls were determined by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA), followed by Dunnett’s test. A P-value of less than 0.05 was considered significant.

sections.heading: Characterizations of nanomaterials
sections.text: The morphologies of G, GO and GQDs were observed by TEM and SEM. G or GO sheets are flat in single layers and smooth with a few folds, and the lateral size in the range of 0.5 to 5μm, whereas thickness is in the range 0.8 to 1.2 nm (Fig. 1A,B). However, GQDs are extensively uniform in granules, and the average size is lower than 15nm (Fig. 1C). SEM images of G and GO revealed the detailed morphology of G or GO sheets. It showed the abundant folds and tubers on the surface of these nanomaterials (Fig. 1D,E). The PLE spectrum of GQDs showed the emission peak at 380 nm under 475-nm excitation conditions (Fig. 1F). The luminescence of GQDs is similar to a previous observation (Cai et al., 2015). It is deemed to be caused by electron transitions from a π orbital to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital. The photometric property of GQDs is linked to assignment of an n π* electronic transition in term of a previous study (Huang et al., 2015). The XPS of G,GO and GQDs showed two peaks at 284 and 532eV, which were, respectively, corresponding to C1s and O1s spikes (Fig. 1G–I).

sections.heading: Lethal effects
sections.text:
After exposure to the same concentrations of G, GO or GQDs, the survival percentages of nematodes were, respectively, assayed. Results showed that 100mg l 1 or above GQDs had no impact on the survival of nematodes (Fig. 2). However, 100mg l 1 G caused a slight reduction in the survival rate. After exposure to GO, the survival percentages decreased in dose-dependent manners. Especially, 100mg l 1 GO-induced nematodes all die (Fig. 2). These results indicate that GO presents strong lethality to nematodes, in comparison with corresponding concentrations of G or GQDs. We also observed obvious inhibition effects on body lengths of nematodes after being exposed to three nanomaterials in concentration-dependent manners (Supporting Information Fig. 1).
Distribution of graphene-based nanomaterials in C. elegans
After 6-day exposure, the in vivo biodistribution of three nanomaterials were further tested. Results showed a high accumulation of G and GO in the pharynx and intestine in C. elegans (Fig. 3A,B). G or GO particles were obviously visible throughout the digestive system, from the lumen of the pharynx
J. Appl. Toxicol. 2017 Copyright © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/jat
to the gut lumen and rectum. GQDs were also found in the digestive system, mostly the gut lumen. Also, there were detectable fluorescent signals of GQDs in muscle and other
visceral organs of the nematode body (Fig. 3C). Additionally, the fluorescence intensity of GQDs in nematodes was increased in a dose-dependant manner at exposure concentrations of 5–100mg/L (Fig. 3D,E). These results hint that the distribution of graphene-based nanomaterials is involved with the possible entry and potential toxicity to nematodes.
Effects of graphene-based nanomaterials on locomotor behaviors
Locomotor behavior assays are well-established protocols for studying the neurotoxicity of C. elegans. Locomotor behaviors including body bends, head thrashes and pharynx pumping were respectively examined. Results showed that 5mg l 1 and above G nanoparticle exposure caused significant reductions in the number of body bends; higher than 10mg l 1 G resulted in a significant decrease in pharynx pumping; however, only 50 and 100mg l 1 G induced a significant reduction in the number of head thrashes after compared with the control worms (Fig. 4A–C). 10mg l 1 and above GO nanoparticles caused significant reductions in the number of body bends, head thrashes and pharynx pumping in namatodes (Fig. 4 A-C). We observed significant decreases of body bends, head thrashes and pharynx pumping in worms after exposed to 100mg/L GQDs; but these changes were not obvious in low concentration GQDs groups (Fig. 4A-C).
Furthermore, crawling videos of nematodes were collected and then analyzed off-line after exposure to three graphene-
Figure 1. Physicochemical properties of graphene-based nanomaterials. (A–C) transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image of ultrathin graphene nanosheets (A), graphene oxide nanosheets (B) and graphene quantum dots (GQDs) (C); (D, E) scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of an ultrathin graphene nanosheet (D) and graphene oxide nanosheets (E); (F) Photoluminescence excitation (PLE) spectrum of GQDs excited by 475 nm; (G-I) XPS spectrum of grapheme (G), graphene oxide nanosheets (H) and GQDs (I).
J. Appl. Toxicol. 2017Copyright © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/jat
based nanomaterials. By analysis of videos, crawling track lines of the exposed and controlled nematodes were, respectively, presented in a same X/Y axis system for three nanomaterial groups (Fig. 4D–F). Compared with the control nematodes, obvious reductions in crawling distance was found in the exposed worms, especially after exposure to 5mg l 1 and above G or GO, and 10mg l 1 and above GQDs. Additionally, the mean speed, bending angle-frequency and wavelength of the crawling movement were further analyzed by WormLab software. Results showed that higher than 5mg l 1 of three graphene-based nanomaterials could cause significant decreases in the mean speed of crawling (Fig. 4G). The bending angle was quantified as deviations from the midline using the midpoint of the body as a reference; and the bending angle-frequency was the reciprocal of the number of changes in the angle (Li et al., 2016). Compared with the controls, significant decreases in reversal frequency were observed in worms after being exposed to 5–100mg l 1G, 10mg l 1 and above GO/GQDs suspension (Fig. 4H). The wavelength is an important endpoint of the crawling movement of C. elegans, which showed the coordination and balance of movement (Tsalik and Hobert, 2003). Results showed that 50mg l 1 and above G nanoparticles,
5mg l 1 and above GO nanoparticles, or 100mg l 1 GQDs caused significant reductions in the crawling wavelength in nematodes (Fig. 4I).
Effects of graphene-based nanomaterials on dopaminergic neurons
The dopamine pathway plays important roles in the modulation of locomotion behavior (Sawin et al., 2000). Herein, the potential effects of three graphene-based nanomaterials on dopaminergic neurons were investigated to explore their neurotoxicity. Figure 5A, B showedmorphological patterns of dopamine neurons labeledwith dat-1::GFP in transgenic strain BZ555 nematodes. Four bilaterally symmetric pairs of dopamine neurons included three pairs within the head, two pairs of CEP neurons and one pair of anterior deirids (ADE) neurons, and one pair of posterior deirids (PDE) neurons in the tail. After exposure to three graphene-based nanomaterials, the fluorescence intensity of GFP in dopaminergic neurons was quantized and analyzed (Nass et al., 2001). Results showed that 50mg l 1 and above G, 10mg l 1 and above GO nanoparticles, 100mg l 1 GQDs caused a significant decrease in the fluorescence intensity of dopamine neurons, especially in
Figure 3. Distribution of graphene-based nanomaterials in Caenorhabditis elegans. (A, B) Distribution of graphene (A) and GOnanoplatelets (B) in C. elegans after exposure; (C) Distribution of GQDs in C. elegans after exposure, a merged image of fluorescence and optical microscope; (D) Fluorescence images of C. elegans after exposure to different concentrations of GQDs; (E) The fluorescence intensity in C. elegans after exposure to GQDs with different concentrations. ***P< 0.001, when compared with the control. Nematodes were exposed for 6 days from L1-larvae. Data were expressed as the mean ± SEM of four replicates. Bar =200 μm.
J. Appl. Toxicol. 2017 Copyright © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/jat
ADE/PDE neurons (Fig. 5C–I). Morphologic changes in dopamine neurons in the head were mainly investigated. We observed the obvious loss of the associated dentrite and soma of CEP and ADE neurons (Fig. 5C–H). Therefore, these results indicated the neuronal damages in dopamine neurons influenced by chronic exposure to these nanoparticles.
Effects of graphene-based nanomaterials on GABAergic neurons
The GABA system also plays an important role in basic motor functions of the worms (Shen et al., 2016). GABAergic neurons are comprised of RMEs, D-type neurons, RIS, AVL and DVB (Fig. 6A). In transgenic strain EG1285 nematodes, GABA neurons expressed the green fluorescent protein driven by the promoter of unc-47:: GFP (Fig. 6B). After exposure to three graphene-based nanomaterials, the morphology and fluorescent intensity of GABAergic neurons were examined. We observed some slight damages in GABAergic neurons, for example, broken off ciliated dendrites, especially in the high concentration G, GO or GQDs groups (Fig. 6C–H). However, there were not any significant changes in the GFP fluorescent intensity between control and exposed worms (Fig. 6I).
Effects of graphene-based nanomaterials on glutamatergic neurons
Glutamatergic neurons are comprised of 16 different anatomical types, a total of 34 cells (Lee et al., 1999; Mano et al., 2007). In the transgenic strain DA1240 nematodes, glutamatergic neurons were labeled using the green fluorescent protein encoded by eat-4::GFP (Fig. 7A). After exposure, the morphology of glutamatergic neurons was systematically examined. We observed a obvious loss of soma and their associated dentrites of glutamatergic neurons in exposed worms, especially in the high-concentration groups (Fig. 7B–E). We also observed the simultaneous occurrence of glutamatergic neurons and GQDs in worms (Fig. 7F,G), and found some slight damage in the axon
and dendrite of glutamatergic neurons. The fluorescent intensity of GFP was further analyzed in G and GO exposure groups. Quantized results showed that 10 or 50mg l 1 GO, and 100mg l 1 G suspension induced significant decreases in fluorescence intensity in comparison with the control nematodes. However, the fluorescence intensity of glutamatergic neurons was not compared between GQDs exposed and control worms, because of green fluorescence disturbance of GQDs.

sections.heading: Lethal toxicity
sections.text:
In the present study, our results revealed the different lethality of graphene, GO nanoplatelets and GQDs after chronic exposure. GO nanoplatelets possessed strong lethal toxicity to nematodes at concentrations of 50–100mg l 1; however, G or GQDs did not show obvious lethality at a corresponding concentration level. It is the first comparative study on systemic toxicity between three graphene-family nanomaterials. The number of in vivo toxicity studies of graphene and GO nanomaterials had increased recently (Zanni et al., 2012; Zhang et al., 2012; Wu et al., 2013; Lalwani et al., 2016). However, there are conflicting results about the systemic toxicity of graphenebased nanomaterials between various test organisms. For example, no signs of toxicity were observed in rats after intravenous administration of dextran functionalized graphene nanoplatelets (Kanakia et al., 2015). PEG functionalized graphene nanosheets also did not show any lethal toxicity in the exposed mice (Yang et al., 2010). Otherwise, acute vein injection exposure of 0.4mg of GO suspension induced mice death (Wang et al., 2011). In C. elegans, 5–20mg ml––1 polymer-coated GO significantly reduced the resistance and led to animal death (Zhang et al., 2012). Additionally, intraperitoneal injection of GO caused mice death, but GQD appeared to have a low toxicity (Chong et al., 2014). Considering that the mean life span of C. elegans is approximately 2weeks, the duration of 6 days in this study is long-term exposure. Our results indicate that graphene
J. Appl. Toxicol. 2017 Copyright © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/jat
nanoplatelets and GQDs possess relatively low lethality on organisms, but GO nanoplatelets can cause systemic toxicity under chronic exposure condition.

sections.heading: Biodistribution
sections.text:
In vivo study of the biodistribution and accumulation of graphene nanomaterial is a base for understanding the risks associated with their uses. We afterwards investigated the biodistribution of three graphene-family nanomaterials in worms. Results showed that G or GO nanoparticles were mainly distributed in the digestive system, whereas GQDs were visible in muscle and other visceral organs of the nematode body. Concerning a smaller size of GQDs than G and GO nanoplatelets, our results indicate that the lateral size of nanomaterials is an impact on organ distribution and accumulation in organisms. Previous studies based on larger animals showed nanoparticles could be transported and redistributed in the liver, lungs, spleen, heart, kidney and bone marrow owing to material and surface properties, after administration throughout the host tissues (Yang et al., 2013b; Chong et al., 2014). In another study, the biodistribution of GO was observed to accumulate in the lungs, liver and spleen, then taken up by mononuclear phagocytes in the reticuloendothelial system of mice (Zhang et al., 2011). Graphene nanosheets were observed to remain in the body of mice for more than 1month after administration, entrapped in the lung, bone, muscle and brain (Yang et al., 2011). Wu et al. (2014) showed prolonged exposure to 0.5–100mg l 1 GO caused its distribution in the intestine and reproductive organs in C. elegans. Using an imaging technique based on Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), another study analyzed the spatial distribution of graphite nanoplatelets inside nematodes (Zanni et al., 2012). These biodistribution reports including ours will be beneficial to
understand the risks of graphene-based nanomaterials on organisms.

sections.heading: Behavioral deficits
sections.text:
Graphene family nanomaterials have largely benefited neurosurgery with the application of drug delivery for brain tumour treatment, intracranial and spinal biocompatible devices, and bioimaging techniques. Therefore, potentialities or risks of these nanomaterials on the nervous system have emerged. However, there was limited in vivo data on the neural effects of graphene-based nanomaterials. In the present study, multiple endpoints were utilized to evaluate the potential effects of behavior toxicity in C. elegans. Our results showed significant decreases in body bends, head thrashes and the pharynx pumping frequency of worms after exposure to high concentrations (10– 100mg l 1) of graphene-based nanomaterials. It indicates obvious locomotor deficits of nematodes owing to the interaction with these nanoparticles. Furthermore, the crawling behavior of nematodes was analyzed after chronic exposure. Results showed high dosage of these nanomaterials caused a significant reduction of crawling speed. Moreover, we found significant decreases in reversal frequency and a reduction in crawling wavelength in nematodes, which hints the deficit in coordination and balance of movement induced by graphene-based nanomaterials.
Observable animal behaviors are a response to perceived changes in the internal state of their bodies or the external environment (Barnard, 2004). According to previous studies, the administration of CuO nanoparticles was shown to negatively impact cognitive function in rats (An et al., 2012). Graphene nanosheets exposure was also observed to impair vital behaviors, including locomotion, learning and memory, and deemed to damage neuronal systems (Yang et al., 2011). However, in a recent
Figure 7. Effect of graphene-based nanomaterials on glutamatergic neurons in C. elegans. (A) The images of morphological patterns of glutamatergic neurons labeled with eat-4::GFP in the control worm. (B–E) Fluorescent images show glutamatergic neurons in worms after being exposed to 50, 100mg l 1 G (B, C), and 10, 50mg l 1 GO (D, E), respectively; (F-G) Fluorescent images show simultaneous glutamatergic neurons and GQDs in worms after being respectively exposed to 50 (F) and 100mg l 1 GQDs (G); (H) The fluorescence intensity of glutamatergic neurons in C. elegans after being exposed to G or GO suspension. White arrows indicate damages of glutamatergic neurons. Red arrows show distributions of GQDs. Bars represent means ± SEM of four independent experiments. Nematodes were exposed for 6 days from L1-larvae. * P< 0.05, **P< 0.01, when compared to the control. Bar =200μm.
J. Appl. Toxicol. 2017Copyright © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/jat
report, reduced graphene oxide (r-GO) nanosheets showed little change in exploratory, anxiety-like, or learning and memory behaviors, although general locomotor activity, balance and neuromuscular coordination were initially affected in mice (Zhang et al., 2015). A series of studies have suggested that nanomaterials elicit toxicity to C. elegans (Wang, 2016; Yang et al., 2016; Zhao et al., 2016). Wu et al. (2013) also observed a significant decrease in locomotion behavior in 10–100mg l 1 GO-exposed nematodes as reflected by endpoints of head thrash and body bend (Wu et al., 2013). The present study indicates multiple endpoint behavior defects induced by chronic exposure to three graphene-family nanomaterials.

sections.heading: Neural damages
sections.text:
In C. elegans, dopaminergic, GABAergic and glutamatergic signaling function is mostly involved in regulation of motor function (Bianco, 2013; Ou et al., 2016). Therefore, we further investigated the potential toxicity of graphene-family nanomaterials on these neuron types in vivo. After chronic exposure, neural damage as measured by GFP expression level was evident. We found the dose-dependent neuron damage induced by these nanomaterials. High concentrations of G and GO nanoparticles obviously impaired dopaminergic and glutamatergic neurons. There was visible loss of the associated dendrite and soma in the damaged neurons. Additionally, our results demonstrated that dopaminergic and glutamatergic neurons are more vulnerable to graphene-family nanomaterialinduced damage than GABAergic neurons. Depending on the application dose of nanomaterial, different neuron populations can be damaged. It is thus important to have multiple markers of neuron damage when assessing the differential vulnerability of subpopulations of neurons to nanomaterials. Previous works have used the level of GFP expression as an indicator of neurodegeneration (Settivari et al., 2009; Harrison et al., 2013; Li et al., 2016). However, gene expression can be altered, upregulated or downregulated, in the absence of overt structural damage (Harrison et al., 2013; Xu et al., 2016). Indeed, a previous report demonstrated manganese-dependent downregulation of gene expression within 30min, long before observable neurodegeneration was evident (Settivari et al., 2009).
In the present study, we directly assessed several markers of neurodegeneration in specific subtypes of neurons including dopaminergic, glutamatergic, and GABA neurons, as well as behaviors governed by these neuronal subtypes. Our results, both functional and structural, demonstrate that dopamine neurons are most vulnerable to graphene-family nanomaterial exposure, followed by glutamatergic neurons. GABA neurons were hardly damaged by G or GO under our exposure condition. Another study showed the intestine was the primary targeted organ for GO in C. elegans; and neurons and reproductive organs were important secondary targeted organs (Wu et al., 2014). Our findings show for the first time that functional (behavioral) impairments induced by graphene-relative nanomaterials can occur in the absence of observable damage to special neurons. Previous in vitro assays demonstrated that graphene and GO can cause dose-dependent oxidative stress in cells, and resulted in cytotoxicity (Zhang et al., 2010a; Shang et al., 2014). GO or rGO decreased cell adhesion; induced cell apoptosis; and entered lysosomes, mitochondria, cell nuclei and endoplasm (Chatterjee et al., 2014). In PC12 cells, graphene and rGO caused cytotoxic effects and mitochondrial injury, such as the release of lactate
dehydrogenase, an increase in the activation of caspase-3 and the generation of ROS (Zhang et al., 2010b). Considering that C. elegans lacks a functional blood–brain barrier, nanomaterials have more opportunities for interaction with neurons. We hypothesized that the underlying mechanism of neurotoxicity of graphene-family nanomaterials might be involved in oxide damage of neurons; however, the detailed mechanisms still require further investigation.
Comparative toxicity between G, GO and GQDs
In the present study, lethal, behavioral and neural toxicity in nematodes was fully compared between G, GO and GQDs exposure. We found GO had stronger lethality to nematodes than G or GQDs. Under sub-lethal exposure condition, three nanoparticles had similar effects on behavior and neural toxicity on nematodes. The biological effects of multiple graphene forms must be taken into account because these nanomaterials possess unique physicochemical properties. Our assay results showed G and GO nanoplatelets had a bigger size than GQDs. In contrast, hydrophobic agglomerates of GO nanoplatelets in aqueous solution hinder their biocompatibility and availability to nematodes and thus become more toxic in C. elegans. Another study showed that graphene nanoparticles exhibited higher toxicity than GOs in Beas2B cells; but GOs had stronger reproductive toxicity in the worms than graphene (Nivedita et al., 2015). The possible reasons for the differential toxicity lay in their distinctive physicochemical characteristics and agglomeration behavior in the exposure media. For the first time, our study compared the toxicity of GQDs and G/GO nanoplatelets in vivo. We found GQDs possess relatively low lethality and neurotoxicity. It is consistent with previous studies on risk evaluation on GQDs. For instance, GQDs prepared using the oxidation approach exhibited no apparent in vitro and in vivo toxicity (Chong et al., 2014). Additionally, GQDs with various functional groups (NH2, COOH or CO-N (CH3)2) showed low cytotoxicity to A549 cells in spite of various chemical modifications (Yuan et al., 2014). Taken together, these results indicate that the toxicity of graphene-family nanomaterials is dependent on the graphene nanomaterial’s physicochemical property, including surface functionalization, particle diameter and a number of layers, and obviously on the alternative model systems used for toxicity assessment. Among various applications of carbon nanomaterials, the biomedical applications especially drug delivery and diagnostic usage of the carbon structures; the potential risks of graphenefamily nanomaterials have been attracting increasing concerns in recent years (Shao et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2010b; Akhavan and Ghaderi, 2010; Yang et al., 2012; Akhavan et al., 2012). We believe that the data presented in this paper would have the potentiality to be used in the field of occupational and human health risk assessment as well as the biomedical application domain. In addition, so far most of the nanomaterials released into the environment, and the predicted environmentally relevant concentrations for carbon nanotubes are 6.6–31.5 ng l 1 for sewage treatment plant effluent (Gottschalk et al., 2009; Doudrick et al., 2012;). Our data also implies various risks of graphene-family nanomaterials to environmental organisms after release into the environment. These results will shed light on the further design of surface modification of technology to reduce or prevent the adverse effects of graphene-family nanomaterials on environmental organisms.
J. Appl. Toxicol. 2017 Copyright © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/jat

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In conclusion, we have studied characterization, biodistribution, behaviour and neural toxicity of three graphene-based nanomaterials using C. elegans as an assay system. Our data demonstrated that chronic exposure to 50–100mg l 1 GO nanoparticles induced lethal toxicity, but the same dosage of G and GQDs showed low lethality in nematodes. Furthermore, we found similar neurotoxicity induced by sublethal exposure to three nanomaterials. Their exposure resulted in significant declines in body bending, head thrashing and pharynx pumping frequency. In addition, the mean speed, bending angle-frequency and wavelength of the crawling movement were significantly decreased after exposure. Moreover, high concentrations of graphene-based nanomaterials induced down-expression of dat-1 and eat-4P, but no significant changes in unc-47. It indicates that graphene-based nanomaterials can lead to damages of dopaminergic and glutamatergic neurons. These results suggest that the chronic neurotoxicity risk of behavioral deficits and neural damages induced by graphene-based nanomaterials. The findings provide useful information to understand the safe application of graphene-based nanomaterials.

referenceMentions.context: Graphene-based nanomaterials are a family of important engineered nanomaterials with unique properties and potential applications (Yang et al., 2010; Bitounis et al., 2013).
Graphene-based nanomaterials are a family of important engineered nanomaterials with unique properties and potential applications (Yang et al., 2010; Bitounis et al., 2013).
These graphene-based nanomaterials are utilized especially in biosensing (Shao et al., 2010), drug delivery (Zhang et al.
, 2010), drug delivery (Zhang et al., 2010a), diagnosis devices (Akhavan et al.
, 2010a), diagnosis devices (Akhavan et al., 2012) and antiviral or antitumor treatments (Akhavan and Ghaderi, 2010; Yang et al.
, 2012) and antiviral or antitumor treatments (Akhavan and Ghaderi, 2010; Yang et al., 2012).
, 2012) and antiviral or antitumor treatments (Akhavan and Ghaderi, 2010; Yang et al., 2012).
GQDs are a single-layer to tens of layers of graphene of a size less than 30nm and have fascinating chemical stability, electronic properties and photoluminescence (Perreault et al., 2015).
GO and GQDs have various important applications in bioimaging, drug delivery, photodetectors, a fluorescent material and biosensors fabrication (Perreault et al., 2015; Thakur et al., 2016).
GO and GQDs have various important applications in bioimaging, drug delivery, photodetectors, a fluorescent material and biosensors fabrication (Perreault et al., 2015; Thakur et al., 2016).

Given extensive applications of graphene-based nanomaterials, a number of in vitro and in vivo toxicological studies have evaluated the interactions of these nanomaterials with various living systems such as microbes, mammalian cells and animal models (Chang et al., 2011; Yuan et al., 2012; Yang et al., 2013a; Zhi et al., 2013; Qu et al., 2013; Lalwani et al., 2016).

The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has emerged as an important animal model with the properties of a short life cycle, transparent body, ease of handling, well-defined anatomy, and well-described genetic and molecular backgrounds (Zhang and Wang, 2008; Li et al., 2016).

The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has emerged as an important animal model with the properties of a short life cycle, transparent body, ease of handling, well-defined anatomy, and well-described genetic and molecular backgrounds (Zhang and Wang, 2008; Li et al., 2016).

After a minute of recovery, head thrashes, and body bending were counted for 1min and 30 s, respectively (Tsalik and Hobert, 2003).
The crawling tracks, including forward and backwards, were calculated using the midpoint of the body in terms of references (Donnelly et al., 2013; Gallagher et al., 2013).

The bending angle was quantified as deviations from the midline using the midpoint of the body as a reference; and the bending angle-frequency was the reciprocal of the number of changes in the angle (Li et al., 2016).

The dopamine pathway plays important roles in the modulation of locomotion behavior (Sawin et al., 2000).
The GABA system also plays an important role in basic motor functions of the worms (Shen et al., 2016).
Glutamatergic neurons are comprised of 16 different anatomical types, a total of 34 cells (Lee et al., 1999; Mano et al., 2007).
For example, no signs of toxicity were observed in rats after intravenous administration of dextran functionalized graphene nanoplatelets (Kanakia et al., 2015).
PEG functionalized graphene nanosheets also did not show any lethal toxicity in the exposed mice (Yang et al., 2010).
4mg of GO suspension induced mice death (Wang et al., 2011).
Additionally, intraperitoneal injection of GO caused mice death, but GQD appeared to have a low toxicity (Chong et al., 2014).
Graphene nanosheets were observed to remain in the body of mice for more than 1month after administration, entrapped in the lung, bone, muscle and brain (Yang et al., 2011).
Using an imaging technique based on Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), another study analyzed the spatial distribution of graphite nanoplatelets inside nematodes (Zanni et al., 2012).
According to previous studies, the administration of CuO nanoparticles was shown to negatively impact cognitive function in rats (An et al., 2012).
Graphene nanosheets exposure was also observed to impair vital behaviors, including locomotion, learning and memory, and deemed to damage neuronal systems (Yang et al., 2011).
(2013) also observed a significant decrease in locomotion behavior in 10–100mg l 1 GO-exposed nematodes as reflected by endpoints of head thrash and body bend (Wu et al., 2013).

In PC12 cells, graphene and rGO caused cytotoxic effects and mitochondrial injury, such as the release of lactate dehydrogenase, an increase in the activation of caspase-3 and the generation of ROS (Zhang et al., 2010b).
For instance, GQDs prepared using the oxidation approach exhibited no apparent in vitro and in vivo toxicity (Chong et al., 2014).

metadata.abstractText: Nanomaterials of graphene and its derivatives have been widely applied in recent years, but whose impacts on the environment and health are still not well understood. In the present study, the potential adverse effects of graphite (G), graphite oxide nanoplatelets (GO) and graphene quantum dots (GQDs) on the motor nervous system were investigated using nematode Caenorhabditis elegans as the assay system. After being characterized using TEM, SEM, XPS and PLE, three nanomaterials were chronically exposed to C. elegans for 6days. In total, 50–100mg l 1 GO caused a significant reduction in the survival rate, but G and GDDs showed low lethality on nematodes. After chronic exposure of sub-lethal dosages, three nanomaterials were observed to distribute primarily in the pharynx and intestine; but GQDs were widespread in nematode body. Three graphenebased nanomaterials resulted in significant declines in locomotor frequency of body bending, head thrashing and pharynx pumping. In addition, mean speed, bending angle-frequency and wavelength of the crawling movement were significantly reduced after exposure. Using transgenic nematodes, we found high concentrations of graphene-based nanomaterials induced down-expression of dat-1::GFP and eat-4::GFP, but no significant changes in unc-47::GFP. This indicates that graphene-based nanomaterials can lead to damages in the dopaminergic and glutamatergic neurons. The present data suggest that chronic exposure of graphene-based nanomaterials may cause neurotoxicity risks of inducing behavioral deficits and neural damage. These findings provide useful information to understand the toxicity and safe application of graphene-based nanomaterials. Copyright © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
